description: From Middle English beliven, from Old English belīfan (“to remain”), from Proto-West Germanic *bilīban, from Proto-Germanic *bilībaną (“to remain”), from Proto-Germanic *bi- + Proto-Indo-European *leyp- (“to stick, glue”).
Cognate with West Frisian bliuwe (“to stay”), Dutch blijven (“to remain”), German bleiben (“to remain”), Danish blive (“to be, remain”). More at leave.

verbs.description: belive (third-person singular simple present belives, present participle beliving, simple past belove, past participle beliven)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete outside dialects) To remain, stay.
examples: [...] God helpe me so, the best is thus to done. “Rise, let us speake of lustie life in Troy That we have lad, and forth the time drive, And eke of time coming us rejoy, That bringen shall our blisse now to blive, [...]"

description: From Middle English belive, bilife (“actively", literally, "by life”). More at by, life.

adverbs.description: belive (comparative more belive, superlative most belive)

entries.meaning: (dialectal, chiefly Scotland) Soon, presently, before long; by and by; anon
